{{short description|Australian comedian and broadcaster}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Peter Helliar | image = Peter Helliar.jpg | caption = Peter Helliar in his [[Bryan Strauchan]] guise during the 2008 [[Australian Grand Prix]] Celebrity Challenge | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1975|6|16|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Australian | occupation = Comedian, actor, radio & television presenter, writer, producer, director | salary = | networth = | television = ''[[The Project (Australian TV program)|The Project]]'' | spouse = {{marriage|Bridget Helliar|2001}} | children = 3 | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Peter Helliar''' (born 16 June 1975) is an Australian comedian, actor, radio and television presenter, writer, producer and director. From January 2014,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/peter-helliar-has-a-date-with-the-project-20140106-30csh.html |title=Peter Helliar has a date with The Project |last1=AAP |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=6 January 2014 |website=Sydney Morning Herald |publisher=Fairfax Media |accessdate=27 January 2014}}</ref> he is one of two regular hosts of ''[[The Project (Australian TV program)|The Project]]'' on [[Network Ten]] with [[Carrie Bickmore]], replacing previous presenter [[Dave Hughes]]. Previously he was best known for his work on television as [[Rove McManus]]' sidekick on ''[[The Loft Live]]'' from 1997 to 1998 and on ''[[Rove (TV series)|Rove]]'' from 1999 and 2009. He also appeared in ''[[Before the Game]]'' as alter ego [[Bryan Strauchan]].<ref name="SMH" /> Helliar initially worked the Melbourne comedy circuit in the mid nineties, performing in various venues and the annual [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]]. He has performed in numerous television ads, most notably for Fernwood Fitness.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://campaignbrief.blogspot.com.au/2006/08/peter-hellier-frocks-up-for-fernwood.html |title=Peter Helliar Frocks up for Fernwood |last1=Writer |first1=Staff |last2= |first2= |date=2006 |website=Campaign Brief |publisher=Campaign Brief |accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref> Helliar, has been nominated for the [[Gold Logie]], for the [[Logie Awards of 2017|Most Popular Personality on Television in 2017]].
==Television== In 1997, Helliar became a regular stand up comic on [[RMITV]]'s weekly variety show ''[[Under Melbourne Tonight]]'' broadcast on [[C31 Melbourne]], hosted by [[Stephen Hall (actor)|Stephen Hall]] and Vincent Hedger.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.aanet.com.au/~vfok/umt/chronicle/97cast.htm |title=UMT - 1997 |publisher=Web.aanet.com.au |date= |accessdate=15 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.aanet.com.au/~vfok/umt/97cast/helliar.htm |title=UMT'97 - Peter Helliar |publisher=Web.aanet.com.au |date= |accessdate=15 June 2014}}</ref>
In 1998, Helliar became a regular on [[Melbourne]] [[community television in Australia|community television]] [[RMITV]]'s weekly variety show ''[[The Loft Live]]'' broadcast on C31 Melbourne, hosted by [[Rove McManus]] and including other well known Melbourne comedians such as [[Dave Hughes]], Kim Hope, and [[Dave Callan]]. He appeared as a live on-screen guest as well as scripting and recording skits for live playback.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theloftlive.50megs.com/loft4/frames.html |title=The Loft Live |publisher=Theloftlive.50megs.com |date= |accessdate=15 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://onyasoapbox.com/talent/show.php?id=200 |title=Talent :: Peter Helliar |publisher=Onya Soapbox |date= |accessdate=15 June 2014}}</ref>
Helliar rose to national attention in 1999, when he became a regular (aka side-kick) to Rove McManus on ''[[Rove (TV series)|Rove]]'', which aired on the [[Nine Network]]. In 2000, the show moved networks to [[Network Ten|Channel Ten]], where Helliar and the show remained until its ending in late 2009. Helliar also wrote for the show.<ref name="SMH">{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/its-a-date-that-crazy-little-thing-called-love-20130810-2rocp.html |title=It's a Date: that crazy little thing called love |last1=Knox |first1=Debi |last2=Enker |first2= |date=11 August 2013 |website=Sydney Morning Herald |publisher=Fairfax Media |accessdate=9 December 2013}}</ref>
In 2003 and 2004, Helliar was part of an ensemble cast in the comedy sketch program, ''[[skitHOUSE]]'', that ran on network Ten as well as being sold overseas.
In 2010, Helliar joined the [[Seven Network]] to appear on their new "family friendly" football show, ''[[The Bounce (TV series)|The Bounce]]'', alongside [[Leigh Matthews]] and [[Matthew Richardson (Australian rules footballer)|Matthew Richardson]]. The series was cancelled after just a few weeks.<ref name="SMH" />
On 18 May 2010 Helliar was guest co-host on ''[[The Morning Show (TV program)|The Morning Show]]'', alongside [[Kylie Gillies]], while [[Larry Emdur]] was on holidays. In the summer of 2010 and 2011, he hosted the quiz show ''[[The Trophy Room]]'' that aired on [[ABC1]].<ref name="SMH" />
In 2013, Helliar created, wrote, co-produced and co-directed his own eight episode comedy series titled, [[It's a Date (TV series)|''It's a Date'']].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/programs/its-a-date/ |title=It's a Date |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2013 |website=ABC TV |publisher=ABC |accessdate=9 December 2013}}</ref> It was a strong performer, being renewed for a second season, set to air in 2014. The show won the 'Best Scripted Format Award' in the International Format Awards at [[MIPCOM]] 2013 in Cannes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2013/10/its-a-date-wins-format-award-at-cannes.html |title=It's a Date wins format award at Cannes |last1=Knox |first1=David |last2= |first2= |date=13 October 2013 |website=TV Tonight |publisher=David Knox |accessdate=9 December 2013}}</ref>
On 7 December 2013, Helliar was appointed as one of the co-hosts of ''[[The Project (Australian TV program)|The Project]]'' from 2014, replacing [[Dave Hughes]], who had resigned to concentrate on stand-up comedy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/dave-hughes-stepping-down-as-fulltime-host-of-the-project-to-go-back-to-his-first-love-of-standup-comedy/story-fni0cvc9-1226777832279 |title=Dave Hughes stepping down as full-time host of The Project to go back to his first love of stand-up comedy |last1=Dennehy |first1=Luke |last2= |first2= |date=7 December 2013 |website=Daily telegraph |publisher=News Ltd |accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref>
==Radio== Between 1998 and 2000 he was a regular guest on the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC's]] national youth network [[Triple J]].
In 2002, the [[Austereo]] radio network signed Peter Helliar, to appear alongside TV colleagues Rove McManus and Corinne Grant on the weekly program ''[[Rove Live Radio|Saturday Morning Rove]]'', broadcasting from [[3FOX|Fox FM]] every Saturday from 10 am to midday after being pre-recorded the day before. In 2004 the program moved to Friday mornings, allowing live phone callers, and was re-titled ''Rove Live Radio''. It was discontinued at the end of 2004.
In 2004, Helliar was signed to do the breakfast shift on Austereo's Sydney station [[2Day FM]] with [[Judith Lucy]] and [[Kaz Cooke]]. The program was discontinued after its first year.
Still signed to Austereo, Helliar also appeared on the [[Melbourne]] based ''The Arvo'', a daily program broadcast out of [[3FOX|Fox FM]] between 4 pm and 6 pm and networked to other capital cities. It was discontinued in June 2005.
He also has done his own show called ''Pete's Show'' which aired on 10 am – 12 pm on Fridays across the [[Today Network]].
Helliar filled in for [[Merrick and Rosso]], along with [[Rove McManus]], for their breakfast daily show on Sydney's [[Nova 96.9]] whilst they were on holiday. Helliar also filled in for [[Kate Langbroek]] on ''[[Hughesy & Kate]]'' on Melbourne's [[Nova 100]], while Kate was on maternity leave. It was announced by co-host [[Dave Hughes]] that Helliar would begin making appearances on the show every Thursday morning.
In 2008, Helliar began presenting the [[Triple M]] Melbourne breakfast spot with [[Myf Warhurst]] called ''[[Pete & Myf]]'',<ref> [http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/story/0,23663,22530647-10229,00.html Comedian Helliar takes on new radio gig] – AAP, ''4 Oct 2007''</ref><ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/entertainment/martins-get-this-gets-the-chop/2007/10/15/1192300688768.html Martin's Get This gets the chop] – [[The Age]], ''16 Oct 2007''</ref> but the show was axed in July 2009.<ref name="PH" />
==Films== In 2010, a romantic comedy film, ''[[I Love You Too (2010 film)|I Love You Too]]'' was released. The screenplay was written by Helliar and he also co-starred in and co-produced the film.<ref name="theage1">{{cite web |url=http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/movies/i-love-you-too-20100505-ualh.html |title=I Love You Too |last1=Hall |first1=Sandra |last2= |first2= |date=6 May 2010 |website=The Age |publisher=Fairfax Media |accessdate=9 December 2013}}</ref>
In 2012, Helliar appeared in the Australian comedy film, ''[[Scumbus]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/celebrity/daves-instant-role-in-kavalee-film/story-e6frf96o-1225998332117 |title=Dave's instant role in Kavalee film |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2 February 2011 |website=Herald Sun |publisher=News Ltd |accessdate=9 December 2013}}</ref>
==Alter ego== {{Main|Bryan Strauchan}} [[File:Straunie.jpg|thumb|160px|right|Helliar in character as Bryan Strauchan]] For the 2005 [[Australian Football League|AFL]] season, Helliar created an [[alter ego]] named [[Bryan Strauchan]] (aka "Strauchanie") who debuted on the television show ''Before the Game''. The character was the last pick in the 2004 AFL national draft, and yet to get a game for his new club [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]].
For the role, Helliar dons a blonde [[mullet (hairstyle)|mullet]] wig and attempts to play up an Australian [[bogan]] stereotype. The comedy is achieved by self-effacing humour, putting Strauchan in situations that highlight his weight, lack of fitness and general inability while his egotistical personality and delusions of grandeur mean he is completely unaware of these weaknesses. The character of Strauchanie has made several subsequent appearances across different media.{{Original research inline|date=August 2009}}
In the 2009 'EJ Whitten Legends' football match, Helliar broke his ankle late in the game after being tackled. He suggested that this could be the end of his career. {{quote|You could be seeing the end of a great career. Doctors say I won't walk again unless there's two blokes on either side of me. I will always stay involved in football; maybe even coach|Peter Helliar in the role of Bryan Strauchan}}
==Personal life== Helliar is married to Bridget "Brij" Helliar and they have three sons.<ref name="PH">[http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/peter-helliar-talks-about-how-good-life-can-be-when-youve-just-lost-your-job/story-e6frf96x-1225761763662 Peter Helliar talks about how good life can be when you've just lost your job | Herald Sun 15 August 2009. Retrieved 30 April 2013]</ref><ref>[http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/celebrity/helliar-skips-for-labour-ward/story-e6frfmqr-1111117266959 Pete Helliar quits Triple M show with wife Bridget in labour | News Ltd 22 August 2008. Retrieved 30 April 2013]</ref> In 2013, Peter and Bridget, together with their three young sons, backpacked around Eastern Europe. Peter summed up the experience by saying "Backpacking with your kids is tough work but hugely rewarding for everyone. Just like parenting, really."<ref>[http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/peter-helliar-backpacks-europe/story-e6frea6u-1226573853463 Peter Helliar backpacks Europe | Adelaidenow 9 February 2013. Retrieved 30 April 2013]</ref> Helliar lives in [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], in the suburb of [[Ivanhoe, Victoria|Ivanhoe]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.weeklytimesnow.com.au/real-estate/victoria/the-projects-peter-helliar-moves-closer-to-melbourne/news-story/fc2341448611c14c03e6eff27833ef94 |accessdate=27 Aug 2017}}</ref>
